Let $\alpha = \angle ECB = \angle DBC$ and $\beta = \angle CEB$. We have that $m\angle DBC = 3m\angle ECB$, which gives $\alpha = 3\beta$.

Since the sum of the angles in a triangle is $180^{\circ}$, we have that
$\begin{align}
m\angle ABC &= 180^{\circ}-m\angle ACB - m\angle CAB\\
&= 180^{\circ} - 90^{\circ} - m\angle DBC\\
&= 90^{\circ}-\alpha.
\end{align}$

We also have that
$\begin{align}
m\angle ABC &= 180^{\circ}-m\angle CEB - m\angle CAB\\
&= 180^{\circ} - \beta - 60^{\circ}\\
&= 120^{\circ}-\beta.
\end{align}$

Since $m\angle ABC$ is equal in both cases, we have that
$\begin{align}
90^{\circ}-\alpha &= 120^{\circ}-\beta\\
\Rightarrow\qquad\alpha-\beta &= 30^{\circ}
\end{align}$

Since $\alpha=3\beta$, we have that
$\begin{align}
3\beta-\beta &= 30^{\circ}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 2\beta&= 30^{\circ}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad\beta&= 15^{\circ}.
\end{align}$

We also have that
$\begin{align}
\alpha-\beta &= 30^{\circ}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 3\beta-\beta&= 30^{\circ}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 2\beta&= 30^{\circ}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \alpha&= 45^{\circ}.
\end{align}$

Since $BD$ is perpendicular to $AC$, we have that $\triangle BCD$ is right.  Since $BD$ is also perpendicular to $CE$, we have that $\triangle CEB$ is right, and $\angle CEB = 90^{\circ} - \beta$.

Now, by the Law of Sines,
$\begin{align}
\frac{BC}{\sin\angle CEB} &= \frac{BD}{\sin\angle DBC}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{12}{\sin(90^{\circ} - \beta)} &= \frac{BD}{\sin(45^{\circ})}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD &= \frac{12\sin(45^{\circ})}{\sin(90^{\circ} - 15^{\circ})}\\
&= \frac{12\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}{\sin(75^{\circ})}.
\end{align}$

By the Law of Sines on $\triangle BCD$, we have that
$\begin{align}
\frac{BC}{\sin\angle BCD} &= \frac{CD}{\sin\angle CDB}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{12}{\sin(90^{\circ} - \alpha)} &= \frac{CD}{\sin(45^{\circ})}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad CD &= \frac{12\sin(45^{\circ})}{\sin(90^{\circ} - 45^{\circ})}\\
&= \frac{12\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}{\sin(45^{\circ})}\\
&= \frac{12}{\sqrt{2}}.
\end{align}$

By the Pythagorean Theorem, we have that
$\begin{align}
BD^2+CD^2 &= BC^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD^2+\left(\frac{12}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^2 &= 12^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD^2 &= 144-72\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD^2 &= 72\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD &= \sqrt{72}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad BD &= 6\sqrt{2}.
\end{align}$

By the Law of Sines, we have that
$\begin{align}
\frac{BD}{\sin\angle DBC} &= \frac{DE}{\sin\angle CEB}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{6\sqrt{2}}{\sin\alpha} &= \frac{DE}{\sin\beta}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad DE &= \frac{6\sqrt{2}\sin\beta}{\sin\alpha}\\
&= \frac{6\sqrt{2}\sin(15^{\circ})}{\sin(45^{\circ})}\\
&= \frac{6\sqrt{2}\frac{\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{2}}{4}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\\
&= \frac{3(\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{2})}{2}.
\end{align}$

By the Pythagorean Theorem, we have that
$\begin{align}
DE^2+EC^2 &= CE^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \left(\frac{3(\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{2})}{2}\right)^2+EC^2 &= CE^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{9(6+2-2\sqrt{12})}{4}+EC^2 &= EC^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{54-18\sqrt{3}}{4}+EC^2 &= EC^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{54-18\sqrt{3}}{4} &= 0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{54-18\sqrt{3}}{4} &= \frac{9(6-\sqrt{3})}{2}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{54-18\sqrt{3}}{4} &= \frac{9(\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{3})+6\sqrt{3}+9}{2}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{54-18\sqrt{3}}{4} &= \frac{6\sqrt{3}+9}{2}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 54-18\sqrt{3} &= 24\sqrt{3}+36\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 54-36-24\sqrt{3} &= 18\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-24\sqrt{3} &= 18\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-24\sqrt{3} &= 18\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-18\sqrt{3}-24\sqrt{3} &= 18\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-18\sqrt{3} &= 24\sqrt{3}+18\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18(1-2\sqrt{3}) &= 42\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-36\sqrt{3} &= 42\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-42\sqrt{3} &= 36\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-48\sqrt{3} &= 72\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-72\sqrt{3} &= 72\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-72\sqrt{3}-72\sqrt{3} &= 72\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18-144\sqrt{3} &= 72\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad 18 &= 216\sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{18}{216} &= \sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{1}{12} &= \sqrt{3}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{1}{12}^2&= (\sqrt{3})^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{1}{144} &= 3\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{1}{144} \cdot 3 &= 3\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{3}{144} &= 3\\
\end{align}$

This is clearly impossible, so there is a mistake somewhere in our calculations.

However, we do know that $DE^2 + EC^2 = AE^2$.

Since $\sin\beta = \sin(75^{\circ})$ and $\sin(75^{\circ}) = \frac{\sqrt{6}+\sqrt{2}}{4}$, we have that
$\begin{align}
DE^2+EC^2 &= AE^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \left(\frac{3(\sqrt{6}-\sqrt{2})}{2}\right)^2+EC^2 &= EC^2+12^2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{9(6+2-2\sqrt{12})}{4}+EC^2 &= EC^2+144\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \frac{9(6+2-2\sqrt{12})}{4} &= 144\\
